title:
WIP: Identifying Tutorial Affordances for Interdisciplinary Learning
  Environments
authors: Hannah Kim, Sergei L. Kosakovsky Pond, and Stephen MacNeil
abstract:
This work-in-progress research paper explores the effectiveness of tutorials
in interdisciplinary learning environments, specifically focusing on
bioinformatics. Tutorials are typically designed for a single audience, but our
study aims to uncover how they function in contexts where learners have diverse
backgrounds. With the rise of interdisciplinary learning, the importance of
learning materials that accommodate diverse learner needs has become evident.
We chose bioinformatics as our context because it involves at least two
distinct user groups: those with computational backgrounds and those with
biological backgrounds. The goal of our research is to better understand
current bioinformatics software tutorial designs and assess them in the
conceptual framework of interdisciplinarity. We conducted a content analysis of
22 representative bioinformatics software tutorials to identify design patterns
and understand their strengths and limitations. We found common codes in the
representative tutorials and synthesized them into ten themes. Our assessment
shows degrees to which current bioinformatics software tutorials fulfill
interdisciplinarity.
